claim: Food affordability in America has decreased in recent decades.

supporting.text: The Consumer Price Index for food has increased at a faster rate than general inflation over the past two decades, indicating reduced affordability.

attacks.text: The Consumer Price Index for food has increased at a faster rate than general inflation over the past two decades, indicating reduced affordability.
The CPI does not account for changes in household income, which may have risen enough to offset higher food prices.
Median household income growth has stagnated in real terms, failing to keep pace with rising food costs.
Food CPI includes premium and convenience products; staple food inflation may be lower when measured separately.
Even basic grocery items like eggs and bread have shown above-average price increases in CPI sub-indices.

supporting.text: Median household income growth has not kept pace with the rising cost of food, leading to a higher proportion of income spent on groceries.

attacks.text: Median household income growth has not kept pace with the rising cost of food, leading to a higher proportion of income spent on groceries.
Government assistance programs like SNAP have significantly offset food costs for low-income households, mitigating affordability issues.
SNAP benefits often fall short of actual food needs, especially in high-cost areas, leaving many households still struggling with affordability.
Technological advancements and economies of scale in food production have reduced real costs for many staple items over time.
While some staples have become cheaper, fresh and nutritious foods have seen disproportionate price increases, worsening dietary affordability.
Discretionary spending on dining out and premium food products has increased, which distorts perceptions of grocery affordability.

supporting.text: Government data shows that food insecurity rates in the U.S. have risen in certain periods, suggesting affordability challenges for low-income households.

attacks.text: Government data shows that food insecurity rates in the U.S. have risen in certain periods, suggesting affordability challenges for low-income households.
Food insecurity rates are influenced by factors beyond affordability, such as access to transportation and local food availability.
Studies show that food prices relative to income have remained stable or decreased for most Americans, indicating affordability has not broadly declined.
Government assistance programs like SNAP have expanded, mitigating the impact of rising food prices on low-income households.
Despite assistance programs, many eligible households do not participate, leaving affordability gaps unaddressed.

supporting.text: The cost of healthy food options, such as fresh fruits and vegetables, has increased more sharply than less nutritious alternatives, reducing affordability of balanced diets.

attacks.text: The cost of healthy food options, such as fresh fruits and vegetables, has increased more sharply than less nutritious alternatives, reducing affordability of balanced diets.

While the cost of fresh produce has risen, overall food affordability has improved due to lower prices of staple foods like grains and processed items, which make up a larger portion of household budgets.
Staple foods like grains and processed items may be cheaper, but their long-term health costs and lower nutritional value offset the short-term affordability gains.
Government subsidies and food assistance programs have expanded, mitigating the impact of rising costs for healthy foods on low-income households.
Despite subsidies, food assistance programs often do not cover the full cost of healthy diets, leaving many households still unable to afford nutritious options.

supporting.text: Economic studies indicate that wage stagnation for middle- and lower-income earners has made food relatively less affordable compared to previous decades.

attacks.text: Economic studies indicate that wage stagnation for middle- and lower-income earners has made food relatively less affordable compared to previous decades.
Food prices have not risen significantly when adjusted for inflation, meaning affordability has remained stable.
While food prices may be stable, wage stagnation means purchasing power has not kept up with other necessities, making food effectively less affordable.
Government assistance programs like SNAP have expanded, offsetting affordability issues for low-income households.
SNAP benefits are often insufficient to cover healthy food options, and many eligible households do not receive adequate assistance.

supporting.text: Supply chain disruptions and climate-related agricultural challenges have contributed to food price volatility, making consistent affordability more difficult.

attacks.text: Supply chain disruptions and climate-related agricultural challenges have contributed to food price volatility, making consistent affordability more difficult.
Technological advancements in agriculture and logistics have offset some of the impacts of supply chain disruptions and climate challenges.
Government subsidies and food assistance programs have mitigated the effects of price volatility on affordability for many consumers.
Food prices have remained stable or decreased in certain categories due to increased competition and efficiency in the food industry.
Global trade agreements have allowed for the import of cheaper food products, balancing domestic price increases.
